title: Former MLBer Rick Ankiel drank vodka before a few starts to calm nerves
text:
February 20, 2017 6:25pm EST February 20, 2017 6:22pm EST News, Baseball, MLB, English, St. Louis Cardinals, Rick Ankiel The former Cardinals pitcher opens about about overcoming anxiety and what led him to reinvent himself as a position player. Rick Ankiel (Getty Images) 
Updated at 6:25 p.m. ET 
Updated at 6:25 p.m. ET 
Rick Ankiel is known for his epic pitching slump with the Cardinals, then his resurgence into the big leagues after a rough few years. 
However, what wasn't known was that Ankiel used liquid courage in the form of vodka to push him through a couple of games early is his career. 
MORE: Every MLB team's worst postseason memory, revisited 
Ankiel joined host Ryan Kelley on " The Morning After " during Cardinals spring training Monday to discuss his new autobiography coming out in April and dropped a few details on how he dealt with nerves when he was a surprise opening day starter in 2001 against the Diamondbacks and pitcher Randy Johnson. 
“Before that game … I’m scared to death. I know I have no chance. Feeling the pressure of all that, right before the game I get a bottle of vodka. I just started drinking vodka. Low and behold, it kind of tamed the monster, and I was able to do what I wanted," Ankiel said. 
"I’m sitting on the bench feeling crazy I have to drink vodka to pitch through this. It worked for that game. (I had never drank before a game before). It was one of those things like the yips, the monster, the disease … it didn’t fight fair so I felt like I wasn’t going to fight fair either.” 
Ankiel said he also drank during his second start that season, a loss to the Astros, but realized after that alcohol could not be a solution to his nerves. 
It all followed a disastrous 2000 postseason for Ankiel and served as the beginning of the end of his pitching career. He last threw a big league pitch in 2004. 
Ankiel then took a couple of seasons off to recover from various injuries and to reinvent himself as a position player. He worked his way back up to the major leagues from rookie ball as an outfielder and had his best season as a hitter in 2008, batting .264/.337/.506 with 25 home runs and 71 RBIs. 
He retired before the start of the 2014 season. Watch This
